A route of corn stover conversion was developed for 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) and furfural production by a novel Cl-containing resin-based solid acid catalyst (Cl0.3-S-R), which was synthetized by a simple hydrothermal method through polymerization reaction of o-chlorophenol and p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic with formaldehyde. The effects of catalyst types, reaction time, substrate types, solvent types, additional water concentrations and corn stover concentrations were investigated in detail. The high 5-HMF yield of 43.8% and furfural yield of 38.1% (based on the xylose and glucose units) could be achieved from corn stover simultaneously in water/1,4-dioxane at 190 °C in 80 min, with Cl0.3-S-R as catalyst. Furthermore, the catalysts were characterized by SEM, elemental analysis, FTIR, XPS and N2 adsorption-desorption to reveal its physical and chemical properties. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Corn stover 5-HMF Furfural Acidic resin -Cl group -SO3H group 1 Introduction 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) and furfural have been listed as the high value-added chemicals by the U.S.DOE in 2010 [1], which may play a vital role in producing important building block intermediates in the industrial applications, such as polymers, resins, chemicals and fuel additives [2, 3]. Therefore, the conversion of biomass to these biomass-derived platform chemicals has attracted more and more attention due to its ability for replacing traditional fossil fuels, reducing environmental pollution and achieving carbon neutral. Especially, lignocellulosic biomass, with low price, abundant reserves and wide distribution, could be used as a promising renewable source for the production of 5-HMF and furfural. During the conversion processes of lignocellulosic biomass, the fractions of cellulose and hemicellulose can be hydrolyzed into C6 and C5 sugars platform molecules, which are further dehydrated to 5-HMF and furfural [4], respectively. In order to achieve the high 5-HMF and furfural production from biomass, various catalysts were reported in recent years. In the field of homogeneous catalysis, the production of 5-HMF and furfural from raw biomass or sugars were mainly focused on mineral acids, organic acid, metal chloride and ionic liquid [5–8]. However, some common problems such as equipment corrosion, environmental pollution and difficult separation of catalysts would hinder the utilization of homogeneous catalysts. To overcome these drawbacks, heterogeneous acidic catalysts are widely developed for 5-HMF and furfural production from various carbohydrates [9]. These catalysts included zeolites, metal organic frameworks, modified metal oxides, metal phosphates and carbon-based solid acid [10–14]. Among above catalysts, carbon-based solid acids have attracted much attention owing to its abundant sources, low price and tunable surface acidity [15]. For example, Li et al. prepared a heterogeneous strong acid catalyst and 93% furfural yield was achieved from corn stover at 200 °C in 100 min [16]. Zhang et al. prepared the bi-functional solid acid catalyst which can obtain a 90.8 mol% furfural yield from corncob in GVL-water system at 175 °C in 30 min [17]. Teng et al. explored a tin loaded sulfonated carbonized solid acid catalyst and 77.82% furfural yield from corn stover was achieved under 190 °C for 3 h [18]. Although high furfural yields have been obtained from corn stover or corncob with these catalysts, while the furfural was mainly derived from the hemicellulose fraction of biomass. As for the cellulose, which are the major components in biomass, has not been utilized effectively during corn stover conversion. The reason may be ascribed to its stable structure, meanwhile, the strong hydrogen interactions in cellulose would also hinder the access of catalytic sites. Thus, it is necessary to develop novel catalyst to achieve full utilization of cellulose and hemicellulose fractions simultaneously. As we all know, the cellulase exhibited high selectivity for conversion of cellulose into glucose, because it contained a cellulose-binding domain and a catalytic domain which were used to adsorb and hydrolyze cellulose, respectively. Inspired by the structure of cellulase, considerable works have been devoted to transform cellulose to glucose, 5-HMF or levulinic acid by developing the cellulase-mimetic solid catalyst. For example, Shuai et al. prepared a sulfonated commercial chloromethyl polystyrene resin which was used to hydrolyze the microcrystalline cellulose and 93% yield of glucose was obtained [19]. Hu et al. prepared a similar bi-functional solid acid catalyst by using sucralose as -Cl and carbon sources with H2SO4 as sulfonation agent [20]. Shen et al. also developed a solid acid catalyst with sulfonic acid functionalized sucralose, which achieve 61% levulinic acid yield from cellulose [21]. Therefore, dedicated cellulose-binding and cellulose-adsorbing functionalities are successful strategy for promoting the interactions of catalyst with cellulosic biomass. However, the most previous reported catalysts were needed the tedious preparation procedures such as carbonization/sulfonation or polymerization/sulfonation [22, 23]. In this study, in order to achieve the highly efficient conversion of cellulose fraction in corn stover, a novel cellulase-mimetic solid acid catalyst was proposed by a facile hydrothermal method on the basis of the synthesis of various phenolic resins [24 –26]. Specifically, the resin-based cellulase-mimetic solid acid catalyst was prepared by using o-chlorophenol and p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid as –Cl and –SO3H sources, respectively, which can be used as a cellulose-binding domain and catalytic domain to achieve the better conversion of cellulose in corn stover. Furthermore, 1, 4-dioxane, as one of the low boiling point solvents, which would be beneficial for the separation of products, was chosen as solvent system for the corn stover conversion. Herein, an extremely simple hydrothermal strategy for the novel -Cl and –SO3H functionalized resin catalyst was developed for the co-production of 5-HMF and furfural from corn stover. The catalysts ware characterized by various instruments to reveal its physical and chemical properties. Furthermore, the effects of catalyst types and various reaction conditions on the 5-HMF and furfural yields were investigated in detail. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF, 99%), furfural (99%), d-(+)-glucose (99.5%, GC), d-(+)-xylose (98%), chitosan (degree of deacetylation ≥ 95%), o-chlorophenol, p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid hydrate (85%), γ-valerolactone (GVL) and butyrolactone (GBL) were purchased from Alladdin Industrial Inc. (Shanghai, China). Acetic acid, formaldehyde solution (37 wt%), 1, 4-dioxane and ethanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). The corn stover was collected from Bozhou, Anhui province, China. The corn stover was washed by distilled water for several times and dried in a 105 °C oven, then, the corn stover was ground into particles that can pass a 40-mesh sieve. Finally, the corn stover was dried in the 80 °C oven until to constant weight for next utilization. The components of corn stover were determined on the basis of the Laboratory Analytical Procedures (LAP) which were established by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and the detailed procedures were listed in previous reports [27, 28]. And the xylan, glucan and lignin units in corn stover were 31.6 wt%, 20.5 wt% and 22.8 wt%, respectively. 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst The Cl-containing sulfonated resin-based solid acid catalyst (Cl-S-R) was prepared from previous reports with some modifications [24, 26]. In a typical preparation process (Scheme S1), 30 mL distilled water, 0.45 g chitosan and 0.6 mL acetic acid were added into a 100 mL beaker with vigorous magnetic stirring for 10 min until the solution becoming transparent. In the preparation of catalyst, chitosan could dissolve well in acetic acid solution and form three-dimension transparent gel, which can be cross-linked by formaldehyde. Furthermore, chitosan can be usually chosen as an absorbent for p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid and o-chlorophenol. Moreover, aldehydes and p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid/o-chlorophenol can polymerize in the acidic environment. Then, 3.2 g p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid hydrate and 0.3 mL o-chlorophenol were added into above mixture, respectively. After dissolution, 3 mL formaldehyde solution (37 wt%) was added into the beaker and stirring for 10 min. Then, the mixtures were poured into a 50 mL Teflon-lined hydrothermal reactor, sealed firmly and kept at a 120 °C oven for 12 h. After the autoclave cooling to the room temperature, the solid products were transferred into 250 mL beaker and mashed to a paste, then, the paste was dried at 100 °C oven for another 24 h. The obtained bulk materials were ground into powder and washed with distilled water and ethanol for several times until pH to neutral. Finally, the catalyst was dried in 80 °C oven to constant weight and labelled as Cl0.3-S-R. As for ClX-S-R, the X represented the adding o-chlorophenol contents while p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid hydrate was kept at 3.2 g. Furthermore, the S-R or Cl-R were prepared according to above method without adding the o-chlorophenol or p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid hydrate. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst SEM (scanning electron microscopy) was used to reveal the morphologies of the catalysts and the mapping was carried out to analyze the elemental distribution in the catalyst. N2 sorption analysis was used to investigate the textural properties of the catalysts. Sulfur (S) content of the catalyst samples were examined by an Elementar model Vario EL Ⅲ. The chemical bonds of the catalysts were recorded on FT-IR spectra in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to determine the chemical state of Cl, O and S. 2.4 Experimental procedure and analysis method All catalytic reactions were performed in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a stirring rate of 600 rpm/min. In a typical experimental procedure, 0.2 g catalyst, 0.2 g corn stover, 15 mL 1, 4-dioxane and 1.5 mL distilled water were added into the reactor. Then, the reactor was sealed firmly and heated to a given temperature with a heating rate of 5 °C/min and kept at given temperature for a certain reaction time (20–100 min). After reaction ending, the reactor was cooling to ambient temperature naturally. The reaction solution was collected by filtration and the solution was restored into a 4 °C refrigerator for further analysis. HPLC (Shimadzu) was used to quantify the 5-HMF and furfural concentrations with an Ultraviolet Detector and Agilent C18 column. A solution of methanol/distilled water (2/3, V/V) was chosen as mobile phase with a flow rate of 0.4 mL/min. The 5-HMF and furfrual contents were calculated on the basis of corresponding standard calibration curves. Then, SEM was used to reveal the morphologies of catalyst samples. As shown in Fig. 1 , the synthesized S-R and Cl-S-R samples showed an irregular particle structure. The uneven surface of catalyst particles could provide more acidic catalytic sites for contacting with corn stover, which may be in favor of products formation. Furthermore, the specific surface area and pore size are important features for catalysts, the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of all sample were shown in Fig. 2 . The results indicated that the S-R exhibited typical Ⅳ adsorption isotherms with a H3 type hysteresis loop. It is obvious that the BET area and pore volume of catalyst samples decreased sharply after introduction of o-chlorophenol. Therefore, the catalyst containing the chlorine and sulfonic acid functional groups was achieved on Cl0.3-S-R simultaneously. As shown in Fig. 4B, a peak at 168 eV that is ascribed to single S 2p peak, implying the all S corresponding to –SO3H. 3.2 Screening of catalysts for corn stover conversion Initially, acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of corn stover was explored using a series of acidic resin as catalyst. The catalytic reaction of corn stover to 5-HMF and furfural was carried out at 190 °C for 80 min with 1, 4-dioxane-water as solvent, and the results are summarized in Table S1. Comparing with S-R, Cl0.5-S-R and Cl-R, Cl0.3-S-R gave the highest 5-HMF and furfural yields, which are 43.8% and 38.1%, respectively. Besides Cl0.3-S-R, when Cl0.5-S-R was used as catalysts, achieving 41.9% 5-HMF yield, which was higher than 38.4% 5-HMF yield with S-R as catalyst. Furthermore, when commercial Amberlyst 15 (Table S1, entry 5) was used as catalyst, 35.6% 5-HMF and 28.2% furfural yields were achieved under the same reaction conditions. These results indicated that the presence of –Cl and -SO3H sites exhibited a higher activity for the dehydration of cellulose fraction in corn stover. In this reaction process, the –Cl group can play the role for absorbing the cellulose like the binding domain of cellulase and the –SO3H group can hydrolyze the cellulose further. Furthermore, Cl0.5-S-R showed a higher furfural yield than S-R, which implied that the presence of –Cl and –SO3H groups also exhibited a synergistic effect for hemicellulose conversion. It is no doubt that the Cl-R catalyst lacking of –SO3H sites showed lowest 5-HMF and furfural yields, which were no more than 10%. The further comparisons of S-R and Cl0.3-S-R on the 5-HMF and furfural yields from the corn stover were investigated at 190 °C in a time range of 20 to 100 min. As shown in Fig. 5 , the Cl0.3-S-R exhibited a higher catalytic activity than S-R in a shorter reaction time. For example, 34.6% 5-HMF and 35.3% furfural yields were achieved by Cl0.3-S-R, while 17.5% 5-HMF and 28.8% furfural yields were obtained by S-R in 20 min. With the increase of reaction time, the 5-HMF and furfural yields reached to the peak values at 60 min for two catalysts. During whole reaction of corn stover conversion, the results indicated that the Cl0.3-S-R resin catalyst showed a better catalytic activity than S-R. Therefore, the Cl0.3-S-R catalyst can be regarded as a highly efficient solid acid catalyst for conversion of cellulose and hemicellulose in corn stover. In order to test the catalytic performance of catalyst further, production of 5-HMF and furfural from various biomass-derived carbohydrates were also investigated by using the Cl0.3-S-R as catalyst in a water/1, 4-dioxane system. As listed in Table S2, it has been shown that such Cl0.3-S-R catalyst exhibited good catalytic performance in conversion of disaccharides and polysaccharides. The yield of 5-HMF from cellulose, glucose, fructose, cellobiose were 37.5%, 33.5%, 69.3% and 24.4%, respectively. Moreover, the furfural could also be produced from above substrates and the corresponding furfural yields were 6.3%, 4.5%, 9.4% and 2.4%, respectively. The results indicated that the furfural can also be transformed from C6 sugars, thus, the furfural yield in this study was calculated on the basis of xylose unit and glucose unit of corn stover. 3.3 The effects of solvent types and water concentrations on the corn stover transformation Besides catalysts, the numbers of previous studies have demonstrated that the solvent may also play a vital role in the process of carbohydrates dehydration, which can not only be acted as physical medium for the substrate dissolution, but also may be present some chemical interactions between catalyst and substrate [30–32]. Thus, the effect of diverse solvents on the transformation of corn stover to 5-HMF and furfural were performed by using Cl0.3-S-R as catalyst. In this study, 1, 4-dioxane was chosen as solvent for its advantages of low boiling point, which is beneficial for separation from furfural and 5-HMF. GVL and GBL are typical green organic solvent, which can be prepared from biomass-derived furfural [32]. To estimate comprehensively the catalytic performance of Cl0.3-S-R, diverse organic solvents and water were investigated in the same reaction conditions. As shown in Table 2 , the highest furfural yield of 42.4% was obtained with GVL as solvent, followed by GBL (42.2%), 1, 4-dioxane (25.9%) and water (10.4%). Meanwhile, 23.2%, 20.7%, 2.8% and 7.1% 5-HMF yields were achieved in GVL, GBL, 1, 4-dioxane and water, respectively. According to previous literature reports, when the moderate water was added into the organic reaction system, the 5-HMF yield can be improved remarkably. Then, the volume ratio (water/organic solvent) of 10% was chosen to add into the organic solvent. Surprisingly, when the water was added into 1, 4-dioxane, the 5-HMF yield increased from 2.8% to 43.8% and the furfural yield increased from 25.9% to 38.1%. As for the GVL and GBL solvent system, the furfural yield changed slightly and the 5-HMF yield increased about 10%. Furthermore, to investigate the detailed effect of water contents on the products yields, a series of water/1, 4-dioxane concentrations were examined. As shown in Fig. 6 , the 5-HMF yield increased from 2.8% to 26% with 3.2wt% water adding into the 1, 4-dioxane. Then, the 5-HMF yield increased gradually with the further increase of water concentrations from 3.2wt% to 14.3wt%, and the highest 5-HMF yield of 46.4% was obtained with 14.3wt% water concentrations. While the 5-HMF yield had some decrease with the further increase of water to 16.7wt%. Meanwhile, the furfural yield increased from 25% to 38% when the water contents increased from 0 to 3.2wt%. Furthermore, when xylose was used as substrate in Table S2 (entry 5, 6), 72.8% and 69.9% furfural yields were achieved with 1, 4-dioxane/water and 1, 4-dioxane as solvent, respectively. Therefore, these results demonstrated that the presence of proper water in 1,4-dioxane would also be beneficial for furfural formation which may be caused by stabilizing the reactants and transition states with unsaturated CC bonds [33]. However, with the further increase of water amounts from 3.2wt% to 16.7wt%, the furfural yields kept about 38% that did not show obvious characteristic trend. The possible reason may be ascribed to the hemicellulose in corn stover has been hydrolyzed fully with the water/1, 4-dioxane as solvent system, thus, the furfural yield was kept at a relatively constant value with the increase of water amounts. 3.4 Effect of corn stover loading on production of 5-HMF and furfural During industrial production, higher substrate loadings can enhance the economic efficacy. Thus, the effect of corn stover loading was conducted at 190 °C for 80 min using 0.2 g Cl0.3-S-R by varying the corn stover loading from 0.1 to 0.8 g. As shown in Table 3 , the highest yields of 5-HMF and furfural were achieved at the corn stover loading of 0.1 g, which were 44.8% and 42.4%. With the increase of the substrate contents from 0.1 g (0.6wt%, mass ratio of corn stover/solvent) to 0.8 g (4.8wt%), the yield of 5-HMF decreased to 38.1%, 25.1%, 15.4% and 12.1%. This phenomenon may be ascribed to the higher substrate which resulted in the self-condensation or cross-polymerization between substrate and products. Besides, the catalytic sites are not adequate to catalyze the corn stover conversion with increasing the substrate loading. Therefore, further investigation was carried out employing 0.6 g and 0.8 g corn stover with higher catalyst contents (Table 1, entries 6, 7). It has been shown that 30.8% 5-HMF and 30.2% furfural yields were obtained under the same conditions by using 0.6 g catalyst, and the 5-HMF and furfural yields can also be enhanced to 22.9% and 25.5% with 0.8 g Cl0.3-S-R. Thus, the lack of enough catalytic sites may be the main reason for the low products yields. These results indicated that the Cl0.3-S-R catalyst exhibited a superior catalytic ability even in high corn stover concentration, which can be regarded as a promising catalyst in industrial application. 3.5 Discussion of structure-property correlation In order to compare the catalytic performance of our catalysts with some previous reports, the results were listed in Table 4 . Various solid acid catalysts such as HSC-SO3H (Cl-bearing solid acid catalyst) [17], SO4 2−/SnO2-Al2O3 CFA (composite coal fly ash solid acid catalyst) [34], SO4 2−/Sn-TRP (Tin-loaded sulfonated rape pollen) [18], SO4 2−/CX-DMSn (sulfonated tin-loaded diatomite catalyst) [35] and PTSA-POM [25] were used to convert corn stover or corncob, and 90.8%, 84.7%, 82.7%, 66.24% furfural yields were obtained, respectively. The furfural yields from these reports were calculated on the basis of the starting moles of xylan. According to these results, despite good furfural yields from biomass, while a low 5-HMF yield indicated that the cellulose fractions of corn stover have not been hydrolyzed effectively. Notably, the 5-HMF yield reached to a relatively high value of 43.8% in this study with Cl0.3-S-R as catalyst under 190 °C for 80 min. Comparing with other studies, a better 5-HMF yield in this study may be attributed to the presence of electronegative –Cl groups and sulfonic acid. The chloride group (-Cl) could be regarded as the cellulose-binding domain which can form stronger hydrogen bonds with hydroxyl groups of cellulose to weaken intra- and inter-hydrogen bonds of cellulose (Scheme 1 ). Then, the adjacent –SO3H groups in catalyst can hydrolyze cellulose into the oligosaccharides via cleavage of β−1, 4-glycosidic bonds, which can be transformed into glucose further with acidic sites [19]. After that, the produced glucose was converted to fructose, which was transformed into 5-HMF with the help of sulfonic acidic sites. According to the results of Table S2, partial C6 sugars were also be converted into furfural. Furthermore, the proposed reaction pathway of hemicellulose conversion was shown in Scheme S2 [35]. The –SO3H of Cl-S-R can react with ether oxygen bond of hemicellulose to form trivalent oxygen via hydroxylation reaction. Then, the oxygen bond breaks to generate carbonium ions and hydroxyl groups. The former can react with water molecules to form the hydroxyl groups, and the pentose was formed after above reaction steps. Next, the –SO3H of Cl-S-R attacks the non-bonding electron pair of hydroxyl oxygen bonded bound to a carbon atom to generate trivalent positively charged oxygen atom. The positive charge is immediately transferred to the adjacent carbon atoms due to the stronger electronegativity of oxygen than carbon atom, which resulted in the fracture of CO bond, the generation of carbonium ions and the release of water molecules. After that, carbonium ions were transformed to the C = C bond and the ring of pentose was opened in this reaction process. During this step, a water molecule is generated again in this process, and another C = C bond is formed at the same time. Then, after 1, 4-elimination reaction, the trivalent oxygen atom form a plane structure with 120° bond angle. Finally, the ring closure reaction occurred to produce furfural. During the above reaction process, the reasonable distribution of binding sites and acidic sites in the cellulase-mimetic catalyst can also be beneficial for the acidic sites closer to the cellulose, moreover, the presence of acidic sites could also promote the conversion of hemicellulose. Thus, a novel catalyst and reaction system can be regarded as a highly efficient catalytic system for full utilization of cellulose and hemicellulose of corn stover. 3.6 Catalyst recycles The reusability of the catalyst was important factor to evaluate its application in industrial production, the Cl0.3-S-R was used for the conversion of corn stover. In a typical reaction, 0.3 g Cl0.3-S-R, 0.1 g corn stover, 15 mL 1, 4-dioxane and 1.5 mL water were added into autoclave and the reactor was heated at 190 °C for 10 min. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction solution was obtained through filtration and then measured by HPLC. As generally known, it is difficult to recover the solid acid catalyst from the corn stover residue. Thus, the reused catalysts were washed with distilled water and acetone for several times, dried in the 80 °C oven and used for the next cycle directly. As shown in Table 5 , the 5-HMF yields were 43.8%, 35.7%, 29.3%, 18.3% and 7.4% from 1st to 5th runs, respectively. The 5-HMF yield decreased after every run, and the similar result was found for the furfural yield. From 1st to 5th runs, 54.2%, 48.7%, 40.5%, 29.8% and 18.7% furfural yields were obtained, respectively. The decrease of 5-HMF and furfural yields may be caused by the presence of corn stover residue and the leaching of sulfonic acid, which has been proved by our previous reports [38]. 4 Conclusions In this study, a novel solid acid catalyst bearing with –Cl and –SO3H groups was prepared successfully through hydrothermal method via a polymerization of o-chlorophenol and p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic with formaldehyde. The synthesized Cl0.3-S-R catalyst showed a superior catalytic activity in the catalytic conversion of corn stover to 5-HMF and furfural in a 1, 4-dioxane/water reaction system. A promising 5-HMF yield of 43.8% and furfural yield of 38.1% were achieved at 190 °C for 80 min over Cl0.3-S-R in the presence of 10wt% water in the 1, 4-dioxane. The better catalytic performance of the Cl0.3-S-R than S-R was attributed to the presence of binding domain and catalytic domain on the catalyst. Furthermore, the as-synthesized Cl0.3-S-R exhibited a good catalytic activity for various substrates. In summary, this work provided a novel catalyst and reaction system for the full utilization of cellulose and hemicellulose fractions in biomass. coredata.dc:description: A route of corn stover conversion was developed for 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) and furfural production by a novel Cl-containing resin-based solid acid catalyst (Cl0.3-S-R), which was synthetized by a simple hydrothermal method through polymerization reaction of o-chlorophenol and p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic with formaldehyde. The effects of catalyst types, reaction time, substrate types, solvent types, additional water concentrations and corn stover concentrations were investigated in detail. The high 5-HMF yield of 43.8% and furfural yield of 38.1% (based on the xylose and glucose units) could be achieved from corn stover simultaneously in water/1,4-dioxane at 190 °C in 80 min, with Cl0.3-S-R as catalyst. Furthermore, the catalysts were characterized by SEM, elemental analysis, FTIR, XPS and N2 adsorption-desorption to reveal its physical and chemical properties.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient conversion of corn stover to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and furfural using a novel acidic resin catalyst in water-1, 4-dioxane system
